result.markdown: --- title: "Proto music: Credible signaling vs. social bonding" author: name: "Ed Hagen" affiliation: - name: Washington State University department: Department of Anthropology date: "2025-05-28" draft: true image: gibbon.jpg categories: - slides description: "Talk for the Evolution of Music Workshop at the Santa Fe Institute, May 28, 2025" format: clean-revealjs: footer: "[ðŸ›– Home](/index.qmd)" css: /styles.css center: true embed-resources: false csl: apa.csl bibliography: references.bib --- ## Explicandum: proto-music The evolution in the human lineage of vocalizations that are: :::{.center-h} * Loud * Synchronized * Variable ::: ## Signals These evolved to reveal signalers' private information that elicits responses in receivers that benefit signalers and receivers ## Visual, auditory, tactile, & chemical signals :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Signals are ubiquitous * within organisms * within species * between species ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](monarch.jpg) ::: :::: ## Signals are ubiquitous in nature ![](signals.jpg){fig-align="center"} ## Common animal vocal signals :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} * Mate attraction * Territorial advertisements * Alarm calls * Predator signaling ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} * Threats * Affiliation * Contact calls ::: :::: ## Animal coalitions The costs of sociality often outweigh the benefits :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Costs of sociality * Resource/mate competition * Infectious disease * Infanticide ::: ::: {.column width="50%} Compensating benefits * Predator defense * Territorial defense * Cooperative foraging * Cooperative parenting ::: :::: ## Coalitional signaling :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Signals * Territorial advertisements * Predator signaling * Threats * Mate attraction (rare) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Credibility * Existence * Number * Coordination/ cooperativeness ::: :::: ## Human evolution: Timeline ![](miocene.png){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Late Miocene ![](loudcalls.png){fig-align="center"} @wich2002 ## Human evolution: Late Miocene ![](gibbon.jpg){fig-align="center"} ::: {.center} Gibbon duetting: monogamous pairs produce highly synchronized song-like calls ::: ## Human evolution: Late Miocene ![](mmc3.2.mov){fig-align="center" height="500"} Chimpanzee drumming has rhythm [@eleuteri2025] ## Human evolution: Late Miocene Chimpanzees: call composition [@girard2025] Bonobos: call composition [@berthet2025] Orangutans: call recursion [@DeGregorio2025] ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![](pliocene.png){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Pliocene Predation ![](predators1.svg){fig-align="center"} @hagen2022 ## Human evolution: Pliocene Predation ![](predators2.svg){fig-align="center"} @hagen2022 ## Signaling adaptations to predation pressure ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![](mesocarnivores.jpg){fig-align="center"} Mesocarnivores: face badges signal pugnacity [@newman2005] ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![Signaling toxicity](Striped_Skunk.jpg){fig-align="center"} ## Human evolution: Pliocene ![Baboon threat signal](baboon.jpeg){fig-align="center"} ## Coalitional defense against predation {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rienIm7EqO4 width="1120" height="630" start="60" >}} ## Human evolution: Pleistocene ![](pleistocene.png) ## Cooperative hunting ## Human evolution: Pleistocene ![](canids.png){fig-align="center" height="500"} @macdonald2019 ## Credible signaling of coalition quality {{< video https://youtu.be/MB3tZXg729M?si=ijvUSaV54Wv3EA4Q width="1100" height="619" >}} ## Credible signaling of coalition quality Feasting and alliances ![](thefeast.small.mov){fig-align="center" height="500"} ## Signaling summary :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} Miocene ape loud calls * Territoriality * Contact calls ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} Pliocene hominin coalitions * Territoriality * Predator deterrence (pugnacity) ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} Pleistocene *Homo* coalitions * Territoriality * Feasting and alliances ::: :::: ## Against social bonding ## Against social bonding: Dunbar's data ![](dunbar_untransformed.svg) ## Against social bonding: Dunbar's data ![](dunbar_log.svg) ## Against social bonding: Dunbar's data ![](dunbar_substrate.svg) @grueter2013 ## Against social bonding Effects are not (necessarily) functions * Petting animals reduces anxiety [@shiloh2003], but petting animals did not evolve to reduce anxiety * Singing and dancing might (or might not) increase warm feelings, but that is weak evidence that these evolved to do so ## Against social bonding ![](socialbonding.png){fig-align="center"} Figure modified from @savage2021, my annotations in red. ## Against social bonding ![](Dunbar.png){fig-align="center"} Figure modified from@tarr2014, my annotations in red. ## Group cohesion :::{.center-h} * Mutual interest (e.g., predator defense) * Interdependence (e.g., sexual division of labor) * Kinship * Social exchange ::: ## Possible signaling contributions to group cohesion Group-specfic songs and dances provide **information** on :::{.center-h} * Identity * Commitment * Common knowledge ::: ## Questions? ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.center-h} ![](qrcode.svg) These slides ::: ## References

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
